COVID-19 Germany

This blog post explores how the COVID-19 virus has spread in Germany and has impacted in different regions

XITONG HE (Monash University)
09-18-2020

Figure 1: Germany COVID-19 situation Source from:Skynews

Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) became global epidemics and threaten human life now. On Jan 27, 2020, the Bavarian Health and Food Safety Authority, Germany, was informed of the first human case of infection with SARS-CoV-2 in a German national working for a company in the greater Munich area Böhmer et al. (2020).

In this blog, I am going to analyse the situation of COVID-19 in Germany.

Data description

The germany_region cleaned data is obtained from GitHub nevrome, where is provided a tidy format dataset with PKI timeseries about COVID-19 cases and deaths for Germany (timeseries) pandemic outbreak and the raw data is collectd byNPGEO Corona. In addition, the germany data is from R package coronavirus(Krispin and Byrnes 2020) provided by RamiKrispin, which contains COVID-19 data from 188 countries or regions, and the raw data collected and arranged by Johns Hopkins University Center for Systems Science and Engineering. Moreover, the provinces data source is from Trackcorno,providing the latest information about the confirmed case and geography details in each region.

The two datasets are shown as below:

  • germany - daily summary of the outbreak on the national level

  • germany_region- daily summary of the outbreak on the region level

  • provinces - overview of the confirmed cases on the each region

These three datasets are collected the information from 2020-01-27 until now, updating daily by daily data information.

Story 1: Case distribution by Region

Figure 2: Confimed cases by region in Germany

Based on the Figure 2, it represents how the coronavirus disease has spread in each region. By interacting the map graph, Northrine-Westfalia and Bayern has most of confirmed cases with 63155 and 62809, and Baden-Württemberg is the third largest effected region in this coronavirus disease.

Figure 3: COVID-19 Case distribution by region in Germany

Figure 3 shows how the number of death,active,and recovery cases differ in the 16 different states until now. By ordering the graphs with highest total number of COVID-19 case, Northrine-Westfalia was the highest one compared to other states. This might also be due to the fact that it is the state with most citizens and there has been more testing in Northrine-Westfalia. It can be seen that meanwhile in Northrhine-Westfalia, even though it has the highest total case, there are much less active and death cases than in Baden-Württemberg and even more positive active case in Bayern until now. One possible reason is that Northrine-Westfalia imposed lock-down restrictions and stricter social distancing after the meatpacking plant became biggest infection accident in Northrine-Westfalia whcih can reduce more active case to happen Augustin et al. (2020). Another explenation might be that the infected persons in Bayern and Baden-Württemberg are older because of a lot of infections within elderly care organizations so that the death cases are higher than Northrine-Westfalia.

Story 2: The overall case distribution in Germany

Figure 4: Overall case distribution in Germany

The overall case distribution cross time in Germany as displayed in the Figure 4. The confirmed cases have a massive upsurge which are shown from the February to April, marking the coronavirus outbreak in Germany. The factors of biggest single outbreak during this period at an abattoir in North Rhine-Westphalia may be contributed to cold temperatures and an insufficient air filtration system that allowed the pathogen to spread rapidly Goldstein and Lipsitch (2020). Therefore, the highest peak of confirmed cases have happened in April. As Germany focused on acute healthcare measurements in dealing with the pandemic and it has advanced medical system,the recovery cases sharply increased after the outbreak happened and it reached the highest point in April Kluge et al. (2020). Meanwhile, the government in Germany imposed strict lock-down measures to stem the spread of the coronavirus so the recovery cases have more than active and death case after April. The trend of confirmed and recovered cases have been declined significantly from April and then flatten out in July but the confirmed case raised slightly as young people were infecting others at social events and the new school year opened. Moreover, the death case only achieved the peak with 5848 cased in April and then flatten into small number even in around hundreds

In conclusion, Germany has a better healthcare systems and advanced medical conditions which can control the mortality in small number and safeguard people’s health and safety.

Note: All figures are reported up to 15 Sep 2020

Acknowlegments

I would like to thank all the contributors to the following R package: Wickham et al. (2019), Müller (2017), Wickham et al. (2020), Grolemund and Wickham (2011), Schmid et al. (2020), Krispin and Byrnes (2020), Wickham (2016), Sievert (2020), Slowikowski (2020), Carslaw and Ropkins (2012).

Augustin, Max, Philipp Schommers, Isabelle Suárez, Philipp Koehler, Henning Gruell, Florian Klein, Christian Maurer, et al. 2020. “Rapid Response Infrastructure for Pandemic Preparedness in a Tertiary Care Hospital: Lessons Learned from the Covid-19 Outbreak in Cologne, Germany, February to March 2020.” Eurosurveillance 25 (21): 2000531.

Böhmer, Merle M, Udo Buchholz, Victor M Corman, Martin Hoch, Katharina Katz, Durdica V Marosevic, Stefanie Böhm, et al. 2020. “Investigation of a Covid-19 Outbreak in Germany Resulting from a Single Travel-Associated Primary Case: A Case Series.” The Lancet Infectious Diseases.

Carslaw, David C., and Karl Ropkins. 2012. “Openair — an R Package for Air Quality Data Analysis.” Environmental Modelling & Software 27–28 (0): 52–61. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2011.09.008.

Goldstein, Edward, and Marc Lipsitch. 2020. “Temporal Rise in the Proportion of Younger Adults and Older Adolescents Among Coronavirus Disease (Covid-19) Cases Following the Introduction of Physical Distancing Measures, Germany, March to April 2020.” Eurosurveillance 25 (17): 2000596.

Grolemund, Garrett, and Hadley Wickham. 2011. “Dates and Times Made Easy with lubridate.” Journal of Statistical Software 40 (3): 1–25. http://www.jstatsoft.org/v40/i03/.

Kluge, Stefan, Uwe Janssens, Tobias Welte, Steffen Weber-Carstens, Gernot Marx, and Christian Karagiannidis. 2020. “German Recommendations for Critically Ill Patients with Covid-19.” Medizinische Klinik, Intensivmedizin Und Notfallmedizin, 1.

Krispin, Rami, and Jarrett Byrnes. 2020. Coronavirus: The 2019 Novel Coronavirus Covid-19 (2019-nCoV) Dataset. https://github.com/RamiKrispin/coronavirus.

Müller, Kirill. 2017. Here: A Simpler Way to Find Your Files. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=here.

Schmid, Clemens, Stephan Schiffels, Johannes Boog, Martin Lange, and Moritz Aschoff. 2020. Covid19germany: Load, Visualise and Analyse Daily Updated Data on the Covid-19 Outbreak in Germany.

Sievert, Carson. 2020. Interactive Web-Based Data Visualization with R, Plotly, and Shiny. Chapman; Hall/CRC. https://plotly-r.com.

Slowikowski, Kamil. 2020. Ggrepel: Automatically Position Non-Overlapping Text Labels with ’Ggplot2’. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=ggrepel.

Wickham, Hadley. 2016. Ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org.
